definition.text: a way of discovering, by questions or practical activities, what someone knows, or what someone or something can do or is like:

example.text: The class are taking/having/doing a spelling test today.
She had to take/do an aptitude test before she got the job.

definition.text: a medical examination of part of your body in order to find out how healthy it is or what is happening with it:

example.text: a blood/urine test
an eye test
a pregnancy test
The doctors have done some tests to try and find out what's wrong with her.

definition.text: an act of using something to find out if it is working correctly or how effective it is:

example.text: The new missiles are currently undergoing tests.

definition.text: a situation that shows how good something is:

example.text: Driving on that icy road was a real test of my skill.

definition.text:
a 
        
         test match  :

example.text: Australia won the test by 197 runs.

definition.text: to put something through a process in order to discover if it is safe, works correctly, etc., or if something is present in it:

example.text: The manufacturers are currently testing the new engine.
They tested her blood for signs of the infection.

definition.text: to do a medical examination of part of someone's body or of a particular physical ability:

example.text: This exercise tests your reflexes.
I had my eyes tested.

definition.text: to produce a particular result when tested, for example in a medical or other scientific test:

example.text: When they were given a test for HIV, none of the patients tested positive for it.
The cyclist tested negative for banned substances throughout his career.
The houses tested high for radon gas.
During the busy summer beach season, when thousands of people crowd the beach, the water has always tested clean.

definition.text: to give someone a set of questions, in order to measure their knowledge or ability:

example.text: Will you test me on the chemistry I've been learning?
Students are tested frequently.

definition.text: to perform in a particular way when answering a set of questions:

example.text: Nearly 90 percent of the school's eighth-graders tested proficient in math and reading last year.
He tested well and was put on the waiting list for a scholarship.

definition.text: to be judged in a particular way when used somewhere or shown to someone:

example.text: The show tested well with viewers of all ages.
He said that none of the proposed voting systems had tested well in Ohio.
The original script was abandoned when it tested badly.

definition.text: If a situation tests someone, it proves how good, strong, etc. they are:

example.text: You will face a series of physical challenges that will test even the fittest and most determined.
That lecture really tested my powers of endurance, it was so boring.

definition.text: a set of questions or practical activities that show what someone knows or what someone or something can do or is like:

example.text: a spelling test

definition.text: A test is also a medical examination of part of your body or of something from your body:

example.text: an eye test
a DNA test

definition.text: A test is also an act of using something to find out whether it is working correctly or how effective it is:

example.text: a safety test

definition.text: to use a set of questions or practical activities to measure someone's knowledge and ability:

example.text: Multiple-choice questions tested the students’ knowledge.

definition.text: To test something is to use it in order to find out whether it is working correctly or how effective it is:

example.text: We test every component we make.

definition.text: To test people or things can also be to present them with a situation which shows how good they are at dealing with difficulties:

example.text: His generation was tested by a world war.

definition.text: a set of questions or practical activities that are used to measure what someone or something can do or how much someone knows about something:

example.text: The tests showed I had excellent spatial awareness.
We have to take a test to get a real-estate broker's license.
New agents have to complete an online training course and pass a test.

definition.text: an act of doing something in order to discover if something is safe, works correctly, etc., or if something is present:

example.text: The minivans all failed the safety tests.
The material passed rigid tests for flammability.
The tests on the toys found that they had dangerously high lead levels.
If tests show infection, computer users can try anti-virus software.

definition.text: a situation that shows how good, strong, etc. someone or something is:

example.text: The ultimate test of a successful negotiation is when the agreement reached is implemented to the satisfaction of both parties.
The true test of a CEO comes during difficult times.

definition.text: to find out or show how good someone or something is:

example.text: This new project will really put her to the test.

definition.text: to ask someone a set of questions or give them practical activities to do, in order to measure their knowledge or ability:

example.text: We will test your strength and stamina.
We will test new taxi drivers on how well they know their way around.

definition.text: to do something in order to discover if something is safe, works correctly, etc., or if something is present:

example.text: We test every product numerous times before it ships.
The machine kept breaking down when I tested it.
The company is testing for gold in the deposits.
The drugs were first tested on animals.
He tested positive for the disease.

definition.text: if a situation tests someone or something, it shows how good, strong, etc. they are:

example.text: The new chief executive will quickly get a chance to test his diplomatic skills.
Investors in British information technology stocks should prepare to have their nerve tested again.
